content: This document is an instruction guide for completing an assessment for the University of Lincoln, providing information on the format, submission instructions, and assessment support information.
what needs to be done for the assessment

For the assessment, you need to submit a project proposal document in LNCS-based format as a PDF via Blackboard, and an ethical approval form via LEAS. The project proposal should include an introduction (~500 words), aims and objectives (~200 words), a project plan and risk analysis (~300 words), references, and a word count. You should also discuss the project with your supervisor and submit a project registration form or full ethical application depending on the nature of the project.

The project proposal should be submitted via Blackboard through the CMP3753M Assessment Item 1 submission area. Ethical approval forms should be submitted via LEAS: https://ethicsapply.lincoln.ac.uk. The project proposal should be ~1000 words, and should include an introduction, aims and objectives, project plan and risk analysis, references, and a word count.
what sectionsn does the proposal need

The proposal needs to include the following sections: 
• Introduction (~500 words): 
Outline the nature of your project, providing the rationale for the work and relevant background material, with appropriate academic references.
• Aims and Objectives (~200 words): 
Describe the aims of your project (usually 1 – 2), broadly stating what you hope to achieve by the end of project. For each aim, provide a set of SMART objectives that are steps towards achieving it.
• Project Plan and Risk Analysis (~300 words): 
A documented project plan spanning the full timeframe of the project. Timescales and milestones/deliverables should be provided for each of the project objectives. This may take the form of a Gantt chart, with granularity of no more than one week. The risk analysis should identify and explain specific risks, their likelihood, and assessed impact, with a mitigation strategy for each. Generic risks (e.g., illness, loss of data, IT problems etc.) are common to all projects and should NOT be included here.
• References: 
A list of references, in accordance with the University of Lincoln Harvard Referencing Guide: https://lncn.ac/ref.
